claim: Among superheroes published by Dark Horse Comics, those who are not human have an average height of 109 centimeters.
extra_info: average = AVG(height_cm); non-human superhero refers to race <> 'Human'; Dark Horse Comics refers to publisher_name = 'Dark Horse Comics';
reasoning: The AVG(height_cm) for superheroes published by Dark Horse Comics whose race is not 'Human' is exactly 109.0 cm, matching the claim. This includes records with height_cm = 0 (which AVG counts) and excludes NULLs (which AVG ignores by default).

content.text: I'll verify this claim step by step. Let me start by exploring the database schema.

content.content:
CREATE TABLE superhero
(
    id             INTEGER not null
            primary key,
    superhero_name TEXT default NULL,
    full_name      TEXT default NULL,
    gender_id      INTEGER          default NULL,
    eye_colour_id  INTEGER          default NULL,
    hair_colour_id INTEGER          default NULL,
    skin_colour_id INTEGER          default NULL,
    race_id        INTEGER          default NULL,
    publisher_id   INTEGER          default NULL,
    alignment_id   INTEGER          default NULL,
    height_cm      INTEGER          default NULL,
    weight_kg      INTEGER          default NULL,
    foreign key (alignment_id) references alignment(id),
    foreign key (eye_colour_id) references colour(id),
    foreign key (gender_id) references gender(id),
    foreign key (hair_colour_id) references colour(id),
    foreign key (publisher_id) references publisher(id),
    foreign key (race_id) references race(id),
    foreign key (skin_colour_id) references colour(id)
);
CREATE TABLE publisher
(
    id             INTEGER not null
            primary key,
    publisher_name TEXT default NULL
);
CREATE TABLE race
(
    id   INTEGER not null
            primary key,
    race TEXT default NULL
);

(
    id             INTEGER not null
            primary key,
    publisher_name TEXT default NULL
);
CREATE TABLE race
(
    id   INTEGER not null
            primary key,
    race TEXT default NULL
);

content.text: Good, I can see the relevant tables and columns. Now let me query the average height of non-human superheroes published by Dark Horse Comics.

input.command:
sqlite3 "/Users/david/workspace/claimdb/test_dbs/superhero.sqlite" "
SELECT AVG(s.height_cm) as avg_height
FROM superhero s
JOIN publisher p ON s.publisher_id = p.id
JOIN race r ON s.race_id = r.id
WHERE p.publisher_name = 'Dark Horse Comics'
  AND r.race <> 'Human'
  AND s.height_cm IS NOT NULL
  AND s.height_cm > 0;
"
input.description: Calculate average height of non-human Dark Horse Comics superheroes

input.command:
sqlite3 "/Users/david/workspace/claimdb/test_dbs/superhero.sqlite" "
SELECT s.superhero_name, r.race, s.height_cm
FROM superhero s
JOIN publisher p ON s.publisher_id = p.id
JOIN race r ON s.race_id = r.id
WHERE p.publisher_name = 'Dark Horse Comics'
  AND r.race <> 'Human';
"

content.text: Let me also check what happens when we include all records (including zero heights) to see if the claim might be using a different calculation:

input.command:
sqlite3 "/Users/david/workspace/claimdb/test_dbs/superhero.sqlite" "
SELECT AVG(s.height_cm) as avg_height
FROM superhero s
JOIN publisher p ON s.publisher_id = p.id
JOIN race r ON s.race_id = r.id
WHERE p.publisher_name = 'Dark Horse Comics'
  AND r.race <> 'Human';
"
input.description: Average height including zeros and nulls

content.text:
When including the zero-height entries (but excluding NULL), the average is exactly **109.0**, which matches the claim's assertion of 109 centimeters.

The claim states that among superheroes published by Dark Horse Comics, those who are not human have an average height of 109 centimeters. The SQL `AVG(height_cm)` over all non-human Dark Horse Comics superheroes (including those with height_cm = 0) yields exactly 109.0.
